channel.title: Wireless Network problems..?
channel.description:
Alright, i'm first going to give you my computer specs..
[b]Operating System:[/b] Windows Vista X86 [b]Wireless Card:[/b] TL-WN353G [b]Position of wireless card:[/b] Right below my NVidia GeForce 7100 card [b]Position of computer:[/b] 1 foot away from CRT monitor, 3 meters away from router. [b]Position of wireless router:[/b] Near a light source. Right beside my DSL modem, not near any other electronic device. In the same room as my computer.
Ok, now, I had a wireless card before, and it had this same problem, so I brought it back to the shop and got a different brand. Same problem. My wireless card is very slow, and stalls** a LOT. Although I have the vista driver(latest), and everything, it says Excellent connection, and the signal quality is usually over 80%. I'm using WEP-TKIP security. My PSP connects to my router with no problems, but it's slow on the web-browser, with games it's quite good.
Is the problem Vista? Or the card? Help would be appreciated.
[size=8pt]**means the internet does nothing for a period of time[/size]

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

My lamp is not a fluorescent lamp.

But yeah OK, he didn’t say what the light souce was, blah blah

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

Sorry, you’d be wrong there Fluorescent lamps in fact do emit electromagnetic interference. Light dimmers also emit electromagnetic interference.

Try this: turn on your fluorescent lamp and turn on an AM radio. If you move near the lamp you’ll hear some interference on the radio. Now if you have a dimmer dim the lights a little, and the radio will go absolutely crazy with static

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Last time I checked, my table lamp wasn’t transmitting on any radio frequencies, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

[quote=“Rajae, post:13, topic:154150”]K, I found the problem, it was a cordless phone that is usually docked right next to the router. Took the phone away, and the problem has disappeared.

Thanks Schizzo.[/quote]

Just wanted to clarify why this was the case. Most routers/cards operate in the 2.4ghz range, and many cordless phones also operate in the 2.4ghz range. I suggest you buy a 5.8ghz cordless phone so it doesn’t interfere with your connection (I take that back since you already solved it :P).

Oh, and Mopman, it makes perfect sense for him to clarify any electronic devices near the router. I have had many problems where simply rearranging the devices actually solved my problem. (interference)

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @rsc rsc
item.description:
@rsc wrote:

i’d suggest netgear as it is windows vista compatible and has its own connection/setup smart wizard. it is also fairly cheap for a router and a card.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

I guess I was right, I’ve known quite a few people that had a similar problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

K, I found the problem, it was a cordless phone that is usually docked right next to the router. Took the phone away, and the problem has disappeared.

Thanks Schizzo.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @musicmad441 Musicmad
item.description:
@musicmad441 wrote:

Get a better router.!

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Vista is not the problem, did your wireless adapter/card come with software to install it with? if not then go to the manufacturers website and try find your model and download the device drivers, if they give you that option that is.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

On a more serious note…do you have any cordless phones in the house that are in the same area as the router? Or even between the router and the computers at all?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Kamu Kamu
item.description:

Mopman:

I can’t help, I’m just really curious as to why you mentioned a light source… was that relevant?

Hahahahah I was thinking the exact same thing.

You also forgot to mention another vital spec: what you had for dinner the night before the troubles occured.

I’m going to try running it in XP, mabye vista is the problem.

item.title: Wireless Network problems..?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:2, topic:154150”]If you have IE, change to Opera.

And have you tried use a Cable?[/quote]
I use Firefox, and I used IE, I use MSN, I use UTorrent, they all do not work for a while.

I was using a cable before, but it’s always in the way, so now i’m going wireless. Cable works. Wireless doesn’t.

Also, when I try to set a static IP on the wireless device, vista crashes with a blue screen (bug)

Read full topic
